title: Exception cause SIGABRT
vulnerability_information:
Overriding the `to_s` method of an exception and raise it from a sandboxed mruby evaluation result in a `abort()` call from `mruby`. This results with the whole ruby process terminating.

Tested on [4cd4dfc855f0cce18b1ee2f318927c13edb20d14](https://github.com/Shopify/mruby-engine/tree/4cd4dfc855f0cce18b1ee2f318927c13edb20d14)

# POC

```
# poc.rb
class A < Exception
  def to_s
  end
end
raise A.new
```

`$ bin/sandbox poc.rb`

activities.message: Thank you for your report. We've reproduced the issue, and our engineering team is investigating.

I worked on a patch that fixes the issue and add a spec test to reproduce it. Since I'm unfamiliar with mruby API, I'm not 100% sure this is the right way to handle it, but as for this specific case, checking for `message_obj` to be a string should ensure no exception are raised from `mrb_string_value_cstr`.An alternative might be to properly set up proper exception handling with `MRB_TRY`.

Actually, here's a second and better patch that fix the issue. It uses the same function as the `mirb` tool to get an exception message. I've taken a look at other potential function call that might raise an exception outside of an mrb block and it seems like this is the only potential case.

Hi again, and thanks for the suggested patches! As a temporary measure we've made the change you suggested in the second patch:

https://github.com/Shopify/mruby-engine/pull/17

However, things don't quite work correctly if an exception with an overridden `to_s` (that returns a String) is raised. We're looking into whether this could be due to a bug in mruby, and will let you know once we find out more.

We'll also get back to you soon regarding a bounty.

Got it.
I was also wondering why `to_s` wasn't working (It actually returns the exception). Had some time playing around and the culprit seems to be `self->state->exc` being set to the current exception, causing it to be re-raised when we enter the VM again by calling the non-native `to_s`.

@isra17 since we may end up using the patch you submitted (or parts of it) I just want to confirm in writing that you agree to release it under the original project license (MIT License). We'll attribute the patches to you by linking to this issue and your github account if you wish.
I agree to release it under the original project license.

Hi @isra17,

We fixed this last week and I forgot to close the issue. The public reference is here: https://github.com/Shopify/mruby-engine/pull/17 and https://github.com/Shopify/mruby-engine/pull/18 and I confirmed the fix is deployed to our production environment.

As mentioned in your other issues, we'll take a few weeks to make sure our payout amounts are fair across all reports we received and get back to you at that moment!
Thanks for helping improve the security of Shopify Scripts and the mruby project!
